responses: See you later, thanks for visiting

Stay in the shade.
Wear clothing that covers your arms and legs.
Wear a hat with a wide brim to shade your face, head, ears, and neck.
Wear sunglasses that wrap around and block both UVA and UVB rays.
Use a broad spectrum sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of 15 or higher.
Avoiding tanning and indoor tanning bed.

patterns: Are there screening test for skin cancer?
responses: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) has concluded there is not enough evidence to recommend for or against routine screening (total body examination by a doctor) to find skin cancers early. This recommendation is for people who do not have a history of skin cancer and who do not have any suspicious moles or other spots. Report any unusual moles or changes in your skin to your doctor. Also talk to your doctor if you are at increased risk of skin cancer.

patterns: How many type of skin cancer are there?
What are the types of skin cancer?
responses:
There are three major types of skin cancer: Basal Cell Carcinoma, Squamous Cell Carcinoma and Melanoma.
Please refer to this article for more information: https://www.cancer.org/cancer/skin-cancer.html

patterns: How to tell if i have skin cancer?
What are the sign of skin cancer?
responses:
Redness or new swelling beyond the border of a mole.
Color that spreads from the border of a spot into surrounding skin.
Itching, pain, or tenderness in an area that doesn't go away or goes away then comes back.
Changes in the surface of a mole: oozing, scaliness, bleeding, or the appearance of a lump or bump.
Please refer to this article for more information: https://www.cancer.org/latest-news/how-to-spot-skin-cancer.html
